Author: Tomi Kilgore
Text:
Published: June 28, 2017 7:27 a.m. ET EU’s $2.7 billion fine represents less than 3% of Alphabet’s cash position By The $2.7 billion fine slapped on Google parent Alphabet Inc. by European Union regulators might look small next to the internet giant’s cash position, but the impact to investors is a lot bigger...6.1-times bigger to be exact. Alphabet’s stock 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    GOOGL, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   sank $24.00, or 2.5%, to close at a six-week low of $948.09. The selloff follows the announcement of the fine, which EU antitrust regulators said was a result of Google abusing its dominance in search to promote its own comparison shopping service while demoting those of competitors. Alphabet said it disagreed with the decision and would consider an appeal. Don’t miss: Google’s big European fine is likely bad news for Facebook, Amazon and others. Analyst Shyam Patil at Susquehanna Financial said while the fine was “large” for the EU, the negative impact on Alphabet’s finances would be “relatively small.” The company had $92.44 billion in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities as of March 31, according to recent filings, up from $86.33 billion as of Dec. 31. That means the fine represents less than 3% of Alphabet’s cash position. Considering the company generated an average of about $67.8 million a day in cash during the first quarter, it could raise the cash to pay for the fine in just 40 days, or by Aug. 8. See also: How Google’s $2.7 billion fine stacks up against each EU country’s annual budget contribution “Moreover, even the potential noncompliance fines,” estimated at up to $4.5 billion to $5.5 billion, “are relatively minor (less than 6% of gross cash),” Patil wrote in a note to clients. Investors may not be so flippant, however. The stock’s drop Tuesday has wiped out about $16.60 billion in market capitalization. With Patil saying he believed the “downside risk” to the stock price is $850, that could represent a loss of 10.3% from current levels, or another $67.85 billion in market cap. Granted, there could be a larger cost to Google’s business in Europe than just the fine. Patil estimates that total Europe revenue from product listing ads (PLAs) represented about 3% to 7% of total revenue. Based on the FactSet consensus for second-quarter revenue of $25.60 billion, that would translate into a potential negative impact of between $768.0 million to $1.79 billion, although Patil said “the actual impact is likely to be less.’ If Google is forced to include competitor listings in its PLA results, Patil said a “reasonable” estimate for click share losses would be about 25%. That could reduce total revenue by just 1% to 2%, or by only $256.0 million to $512.0 million. That said, Patil reiterated his bullish positive rating on the stock, and his price target of $1,200, which is 26.6% above current levels. For investors, that could mean a gain of $174.26 billion in market cap. The shares have still run up 19.6% year to date, while the Nasdaq Composite Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    COMP, -2.78%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   has climbed 14.2% and the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    SPX, -1.97%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   has gained 8.1%. Want news about Europe delivered to your inbox? Subscribe to MarketWatch's free Europe Daily newsletter. Sign up here.
Title: Google investors take a big $17 billion hit from ‘relatively small’ EU fine - MarketWatch

Author: Philip van Doorn
Text:
Published: June 29, 2017 11:18 a.m. ET Google parent Alphabet is the top holding of the Red Oak Technology Select Fund By How would you react to a 39% gain in a particular stock over the past 12 months? Would you suggest selling it to lock in the gain? Mark Oelschlager, the portfolio manager for the Red Oak Technology Select Fund 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    ROGSX, -2.72%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   doesn’t think this way at all, and he has a very solid track record standing behind his continued faith in Alphabet, Google’s parent company. Despite that 39% increase in both Alphabet Inc.‘s Class A 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    GOOGL, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   and Class C 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    GOOG, -2.58%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   shares, Oelschlager described both stocks as still “compelling.” He cited Alphabet’s 17% increase in first-quarter revenue and said, “the stock is right around a 5% free cash yield, which is roughly where the market is and might even be better.” A company’s free cash flow is its remaining cash flow after capital-spending commitments. This is money that can be used for any corporate purpose, including acquisitions or other expansion. If you divide a company’s annual free cash flow per share by its share price, you have the free cash flow yield, which can be used for comparison The two Alphabet share classes together made up 8.1% of the Red Oak Technology Select Fund as of March 31, by far the fund’s largest equity position. The fund was ranked 17th of 7,581 actively managed open-ended mutual fund, based on average total returns for five years, through June 26, according to data provided by Morningstar. It has $460 million in assets and was established in December 1998. Oelschlager, who is Oak Associates Funds’ co-chief investment officer, took over as the fund’s portfolio manager in April 2006. Before joining Oak Associates in 2000, he was an equity analyst for the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio. Here’s how the fund’s performance has stacked up against its peer group, according to Morningstar, as well as the S&P 500 technology sector and the Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight Technology ETF 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    RYT, -3.15%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   through June 27: Oelschlager attributed a great part of the fund’s success to its focus on the technology sector. But it stands out even among its peers. Among 51 actively managed U.S.open-ended technology funds — which excludes narrowly focused funds, such as those that only buy semiconductor stocks, for example — the Red Oak Technology Select Fund ranked third over the past five years. Also see: No. 1 mutual fund, which made a killing off Amazon and Tesla, is now focused on these stocks Oelschlager said free cash flow yield and price-to-earnings valuations are important parts of his team’s stock selection, but that he also is concerned with the “sustainability” of a business.“ Many tech investors “think they need to find the big stars of the future,” he told MarketWatch in a June 28 interview, but the odds of identifying the next Google or Facebook “are against you.” “When you focus on companies growing the fastest, the deck again is stacked against you because of high valuations,” he added. Another stock Oelschlager is keen on is KLA-Tencor Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    KLAC, -3.14%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   which makes equipment for the semiconductor industry. Valuation is the reason: free cash flow is about 6% and the shares trade for 15.9 times the consensus 2018 earnings estimate among analysts polled by FactSet. That compares with a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 17.1 for the S&P 500 information technology sector and of 16.5 for the entire S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    SPX, -1.97% KLA-Tencor’s valuation looked especially low because it “dominates” its industry niche, he said. “Granted, it is a cyclical, and does not necessarily deserve a high multiple, but they have proven to be fairly consistent and the stock looks like a good long-term investment,” he added. One position Oelschlager has “cut back quite a bit” is chip maker Nvidia Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    NVDA, -7.84%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   after it returned 227% during 2016. According to Morningstar, the fund’s annual turnover ratio has been 6%, which is amazingly low for an actively managed fund. This underscores Oelschlager’s style of sticking with companies showing consistently high rates of growth. “A lot of people are tempted to trade a lot, because it feels like you are accomplishing something by constantly making moves. But often times, the best thing is to do nothing,” he said. However, the fund will be much more active during periods of disruption in the market, he said. During 2009, for example, the fund’s turnover was 30%. That was in the wake of the credit crisis that sent the S&P 500 information technology sector down 43% in 2008. Here are the Red Oak Technology Select Fund’s 10 largest stock holdings (out of 42), as of March 31. They accounted for 37% of the portfolio. There are actually 11 stocks listed here, because the fund holds both classes of Alphabet. You can click on the tickers for more information, including news, ratings, price to earnings ratios, financials and filings.
Title: Google’s stock is still ‘compelling,’ says outperforming tech fund manager - MarketWatch

Author: Mark DeCambre
Text:
Published: June 27, 2017 7:33 a.m. ET Arconic tops S&P 500 losers, down 6% By The Dow industrials on Monday ended a string of daily losses at four, but the Nasdaq Composite faltered, putting pressure on the broader market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    DJIA, -2.32%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   rose 14.79 points, or less than 0.1%, at 21,409.55. The Nasdaq Composite Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    COMP, -2.78%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   shed 18.10 points, or 0.3%, to 6,247.15 as Apple Inc.
AAPL, -5.04%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   dropped 0.3%, and Facebook Inc.
FB, -2.35%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   and Alphabet Inc.
GOOGL, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   dropped about 1% each. The S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    SPX, -1.97%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   finished up 0.77 points, or less than 0.1%, to 2,439.07, with so-called defensive sectors, such as utilities and telecoms, leading gains. The technology sector, which was trading up 0.7% in early trade, reversed course to end down 0.6%. For the first half of 2017, the benchmark S&P 500 is on track to advance about 9%, with some analysts suggesting that the second half will likely be positive as well. “When the 500’s first-half price gain was between 7% and 12%…the market went on to record an average price rise of 5.1% during the second half and posted a positive performance an above-average 87% of the time,” wrote Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at CFRA, a market research firm. Stovall’s calculations would put the S&P 500 at 2,565 by the end of 2017. “While this forward six-month level for the S&P 500 approximates our 12-month target, based on current EPS and inflation projections, history implies that we may be underestimating the market’s rest-of-year potential,” Stovall said. Volatile moves in crude-oil prices 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    US:CLQ7

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   early in the session also contributed to dampening appetite for stocks. Weaker-than-expected durable-goods orders may also have limited gains for equities. Both the dollar and Treasury yields weakened after the release of the report. Durable-goods orders slipped 1.1% last month following a similar drop in April, disappointing economists who expected a smaller decline. “After vast improvement at the start of the year, manufacturers have recorded fewer than expected durable-goods orders for the second consecutive month,” said Lindsey Piegza, chief economist at Stifel Fixed Income, in a note. “Short-lived optimism, no doubt, from pro-growth policies ushered in by the Trump administration have been replaced by a more lackluster reality of a little improved domestic growth and consumption profile.” Read: Want to know where the stock market’s headed over next 6 months? Don’t ask OPEC Stock movers: Facebook 
FB, -2.35%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   declined 1% after first gaining on news that the social-networking giant is talking to Hollywood studios and agencies about producing TV-quality shows, according to people familiar with the talks. U.S.-listed shares of Nestlé SA
NSRGY, -0.89%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   jumped 3.9% following news that billionaire activist investor Daniel Loeb’s Third Point LLC hedge fund has taken a $3.5 billion stake in the consumer-products giant. Arconic Inc.
ARNC, -3.32%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   shares sank 6%, topping the losers on the S&P 500. The company said it would halt sales of one type of aluminum cladding for use in high-rise buildings after at least 79 people died in a fire at the Grenfell Tower in London. The material was suspected to have partly contributed to the spread of the inferno. Hertz Global Holdings Inc.
HTZ, -2.06%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   surged 14% on a Bloomberg News report that the rental car company will be leasing a fleet of its cars to Apple to test the iPhone maker’s self-driving technology. Shares of Yum Brands Inc.
YUM, -1.40%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   closed 0.1% lower, erasing gains from news of Australian company Collins Foods Ltd. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    CKF, -0.55%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   buying 28 KFC restaurants from the fast food-chain operator. Economic news and Fed speakers: The Chicago Fed national activity index fell to negative 0.26 in May from 0.57 in April. See: MarketWatch’s Economic Calendar. A quarterly mortgage sentiment survey from Fannie Mae showed U.S. lenders are preparing for tougher times ahead and planning to relax lending standards, according to Reuters. In central-bank news, San Francisco Fed President John Williams said at a speech in Australia that gradual hikes in interest rates are needed to avoid overheating the U.S. economy. Separately in Salzburg, Austria, Fed Gov. Jerome Powell said he sees room to ease some banking rules in the U.S. Other markets: The dollar 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    DXY, -0.04%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   rose 0.2% against peers while the yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to 2.13%. Meanwhile gold 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    US:GCQ7

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   stumbled 1%. Asian stock markets closed higher across the board, serving as a tailwind for European stocks. —Sara Sjolin and Anora Mahmudova contributed to this article Providing critical information for the U.S. trading day. Subscribe to MarketWatch's free Need to Know newsletter. Sign up here.
Title: Dow halts 4-session skid, but Nasdaq slumps as technology stocks stumble - MarketWatch

Author: Trey Williams
Text:
Published: June 23, 2017 12:14 p.m. ET Netflix’s new show ‘GLOW,’ a fictionalized telling of the 1980s show the Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling, debuts Friday By Netflix Inc. has taken some heat lately for the shows it’s cut from the platform. But those moves, in theory, were made so that the streaming platform can produce shows like “GLOW,” which, if history tells us anything, likely will have a positive impact on the company’s earnings. The streaming giant premiered the debut season of “GLOW” — the Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling — on Friday. According to analysts at Raymond James, Netflix’s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    NFLX, -3.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   share price sees a bigger post-earnings bump in quarters with new original shows than it does in quarters with hit originals. Raymond James analysts found a 0.4 correlation between hit original series and positive stock reaction, but the correlation rose to 0.7 when analysts looked only at series in their debut season. In short, new series outperform returning series on Netflix. “‘House of Cards’ is a great series, but if you didn’t join Netflix for seasons two through four, you are probably not joining for season five,” lead analyst Justin Patterson wrote in a note. “Conversely, ‘Stranger Things’ and ‘13 Reasons Why’ represented hits in different genres for Netflix, which likely led to new subscribers joining.” So it makes sense that Netflix would cancel exorbitantly expensive shows “Sense8” and “The Get Down” to free up coin and space for other content. Also see: Netflix has to cancel shows because not even it can keep spending like this Check out: Should Netflix consider heading to Broadway for its next genre challenge? With a $6 billion content budget, Netflix already outspends its streaming and network competitors, so it has the cash. However, the industry is bumping up against the peak TV ceiling. There were 455 scripted TV shows last year and that number has been expected to close in on 500 in 2017. But there are still only so many hours in the day that viewers can spend watching TV, so it does little good to continue to feed the content beast. In Patterson’s view, Netflix is taking the right approach by canceling shows that aren’t meeting the cost vs. viewership expectations. To judge, Raymond James analysts analyzed Google Trends data for some of Netflix’s canceled shows compared with “House of Cards” and found significantly lower activity for the canceled shows from January 2014 to June 2017. Since Netflix doesn’t release viewership data for its shows, Patterson suggested Google Trends could be used as a proxy for what people are watching and talking about. Also read: Younger millennials don’t know what networks are responsible for TV shows, unless it’s Netflix While some of Netflix’s most popular shows (“House of Cards,” “Stranger Things” and “13 Reasons Why”) have a tough time comparing with the likes of AMC Network Inc.’s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    AMCX, -0.28%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   “The Walking Dead” and Time Warner Inc.-owned 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    US:TWX

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” judging from Google Trends, they better compete with broadcast’s biggest shows “The Big Bang Theory” and “The Bachelor.” “‘GLOW’ is receiving positive reviews and could be a new hit,” Patterson wrote. The show has a 97% rating on Rotten Tomatoes. “If the initial critics are right, this could be a new hit for Netflix and carry some momentum for the company in the 2017 third quarter. “We believe Netflix is being disciplined on original content investment and has potential content catalysts in the second half of 2017 that could drive net add upside. We reiterate our outperform rating and $165 target price.” Don’t miss: More people subscribe to a streaming service than they do cable TV Also read: Amazon’s ability to dominate multiple industries scares competitors like Netflix Shares of Netflix have gained more than 26% in the year to date and more than 70% during the prior 12-month period. By comparison, the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    SPX, -1.97%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   is up nearly 9% in the year and more than 15% in the last 12 months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    DJIA, -2.32%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   is up more than 8% in the year and nearly 19% in the last 12 months.
Title: Netflix shares react better to new shows, like ‘GLOW,’ than returning series - MarketWatch

Author: Steven Kutz
Text: Published: June 26, 2017 1:44 p.m. ET Derek Carr signed a $125 million contract, but says he won’t buy anything extravagant By After becoming the highest paid player in the National Football League, Oakland Raiders quarterback Derek Carr was asked if there’s anything he would splurge on. He answered with a lighthearted “Chick-fil-A,” and then said he would buy his wife “something nice.” But then he said she’d rather he didn’t and that “she still gets coupons…she gets online and tries to find discounts and none of that’s going to change.” “The exciting thing for me, money-wise, honestly, is that this money is going to help a lot of people,” he added. He said he’s been tithing since he got scholarship money in college, and that won’t change now. Derek (@derekcarrqb), now that you're the highest paid player in NFL history, what are you going to buy? pic.twitter.com/q4QbyRwtM0 Carr, 26, signed a $125 million, five-year contract on June 22. The contract pays him more in the later years of the deal, possibly because the team will be moving to Las Vegas in 2020, where there is no state income tax — so Carr would get to keep more of his salary in those years. Many athletes are in the news for making — and losing — millions. But there are increasingly more examples of professional athletes who do a lot to make sure their money will last long after they stop playing. Clearly Carr is an example of the latter. The NFL over the last few years has increased its efforts to help its athletes make their money last. For the last few years, it has held a personal finance camp for players as well as a Business Academy, the most recent of which was held at the University of Michigan in March. See: Why this former NFL star bought a Dunkin’ Donuts MarketWatch has spoken with several athletes who, like Carr, are smart with their money. For example, NFL star Brandon Flowers has made $50 million and only just recently bought his first house. In fact, money managers who work with professional athletes recently told MarketWatch it recommends that NBA rookies rent a home until they sign their second league contract. Regarding the generous tithing that Carr does, here’s a video of him talking about the time in college when he started living the Christian lifestyle.
Title: The highest paid player in the NFL says his wife still uses coupons - MarketWatch

Author: Tomi Kilgore
Text:
Published: June 24, 2017 2:12 p.m. ET Warehouse retailer’s stock suffers sharpest 6-day drop since the Great Recession, leaving management ‘surprised’ By Shares of Coscto Wholesale Corp. continued their retreat Friday, extending the most damaging stretch of losses since the Great Recession, fueled by news of Amazon.com Inc.’s deal to buy Whole Foods Market Inc. Analyst Mark Astrachan at Stifel Nicolaus, who hosted a recent meeting with Costco executives, including Chief Financial Officer Richard Galanti, said the membership-based warehouse retailer’s executives were “surprised at both the deal and the negative share-price reaction,” as they believed other grocers would be more exposed than Costco to competition stemming from the deal. Costco’s stock

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    COST, -1.37%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  slumped 1.7% on Friday to its lowest closing level since Dec. 7. It has now tumbled 12.7% since the Amazon–Whole Foods deal was announced, the worst six-day percentage performance since the stock tumbled 13.4% during the six-day stretch ending Nov. 19, 2008. In comparison, shares of grocer Kroger Co.

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    KR, -0.06%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  are down 8% since the deal was announced. That figure may be a bit misleading, however, given that the shares had plunged 19% the day before the deal after Kroger posted disappointing results. Sprouts Farmers Markets Inc.’s stock

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    SFM, +1.63%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  has slipped just 1.8% since the deal, but it, too, had shed 9.4% the day before the deal, in sympathy with Kroger’s selloff. Don’t miss: Grocery stocks tank as ‘Amazon effect’ strikes fear in investors . See also: Amazon ‘will be a top 5 grocer in the U.S.’ with Whole Foods acquisition. Astrachan kept his buy recommendation on Costco but slashed his stock-price target to $173, which was 10.1% above current levels, from $191. “From a stock standpoint, while Amazon/Whole Foods will not impact near-term results, it is likely to impact industry trends longer-term, which uncertainty regarding strategic plans for the combined entity and the response from legacy participants, limiting multiple expansion, and share price upside, from current levels,” Astrachan wrote in a note to clients. He said that while Costco’s executives didn’t intend to make major changes in strategy in the wake of the Amazon–Whole Foods deal, they anticipated “accelerating measures to enhance the consumer value proposition.” Perfect timing, because a BMO Capital study, published just before the Amazon–Whole Foods deal was announced, showed that prices on Costco’s website were 17% lower than those on Amazon.com, giving Costco a “big opportunity” online. Don’t miss: Costco’s online prices are lower than Amazon’s, study finds. So while Astrachan acknowledged that the uncertainty surrounding the effects of the Amazon–Whole Foods merger will weigh on the grocery sector, Costco, in his view, is likely to outperform its peer group, given its “competitive advantage, including an increased focus on e-commerce and fresh food strategies.” Costco did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Costco’s stock has lost 1.9% in 2017, while the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector exchange-traded fund

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    XLY, -2.01%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  has advanced 10% and the S&P 500 index

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    SPX, -1.97%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  has gained 8.9%. In comparison, Amazon’s stock

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    AMZN, -4.41%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  has shot up 34% so far this year and Whole Foods shares

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    US:WFM

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  have surged 40%.
Title: Costco shares’ worst stretch since Great Recession was after Amazon–Whole Foods deal - MarketWatch

Author: Tomi Kilgore
Text: Published: June 22, 2017 8:02 a.m. ET BORDEAUX, France and NEW YORK, Jun 22, 2017 (PR Newswire Europe via COMTEX) -- BORDEAUX, France and NEW YORK, June 26, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Offering to boost customers' digital strategy by putting rich website analytics data in context with a 360-degree view of the market and competition SimilarWeb [http://similarweb.com ], the leading digital market intelligence company, and AT Internet [https://www.atinternet.com/en ], a global player in digital analytics, today announced their strategic partnership allowing customers to combine data from their own website with market-based information. Together, the two solutions provide a deep view of user behavior placed in the wider context of real-time market insights. The end result is a first-of-its-kind dashboard for strategic intelligence, enabling clients to understand their digital audience and quickly pivot strategies, based on not only their own site traffic, but on insights from the competitive landscape as well. Starting today, AT Internet and SimilarWeb's customers can use the dashboard to inform their strategy based on a 360-degree understanding of their site visitors and the market. "Our alliance with AT Internet introduces a new layer of intelligence that offers invaluable perspective and context from global site or app activity so that clients can make the best possible decision with robust data insights," said Carlton Osborne, VP Global Alliances at SimilarWeb. Jonathan Strauss-Kahn, Partnership Manager at AT Internet, added, "The integration of our rich, accurate analytics data with SimilarWeb's extensive competitive intelligence gives our customers a complete and authentic view of their website and mobile performance - the keystone of an optimized digital strategy." How companies can benefit Through the combination of website and mobile analytics data from AT Internet, and external market data provided by SimilarWeb, digital campaigns and trends can be evaluated for their overall business impact and understood within the context of the competitive market. Businesses can use the multi-layered data in several ways to generate value, including but not limited to: ABOUT SIMILARWEB SimilarWeb is the standard for understanding the digital world. With the largest international online panel consisting of hundreds of millions of devices, SimilarWeb provides granular insights about any website or app across industries. Global brands such as Google, HSBC, eBay, L'Oreal, and Adidas rely on SimilarWeb to understand, track and grow their digital market share. The company has raised $65M to date, and has 350 employees across eight global offices. SimilarWeb has been named one of JMP Securities Hot 100 Best Privately Held Software Companies [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/similarweb-named-to-jmp-securities-hot-100-list-of-best-privately-held-software-companies-615227974.html ] and one of Business Insider's 50 Enterprise Startups to bet your career on [http://www.businessinsider.com/enterprise-startups-to-bet-on-in-2016-2015-11 ]. Learn more at http://www.similarweb.com. ABOUT AT INTERNET One of the world's major players in digital intelligence since 1996, AT Internet helps companies measure their audience and optimise their digital performance across all channels. AT Internet's expertise extends from collecting raw data to processing it in real time and delivering it for analysis and the sharing of insights. Applications in AT Internet's Analytics Suite provide reliable, contextualised and actionable information. Scalable and completely modular, AT Internet's offering adapts to businesses in all industries: e-commerce, media, finance/banking, corporate and institutions. Easy-to-use and accessible to all individuals within a company, these solutions help address the challenges facing both novices and experts in digital analytics and data mining. The power of AT Internet's Analytics Suite and the quality of its services (consulting, training and support) are recognised worldwide. AT Internet's analytics solution is used on more than 20,000 sites and applications around the world, across all industries. With more than 200 employees, the group is present globally via its customers, subsidiaries and partners. Learn more: http://www.atinternet.com Copyright (C) 2017 PR Newswire Europe
Title: SimilarWeb and AT Internet Partner to Empower Customers with Unparalleled Digital Insights - MarketWatch

Author: Sara Sjolin
Text:
Published: June 27, 2017 7:51 a.m. ET Critical information for the U.S. trading day By It’s beginning to feel like a summer lull out there for markets. But a herd of Fed speakers — including Janet Yellen — could break the pre-holiday spell and deliver a last-minute shake-up as this year’s first half wraps up today. Stocks don’t necessarily deserve a boost, with the Dow and S&P on track for their best first half in four years. And the Nasdaq is flirting with its biggest gain since 2003 (though techs don’t look too frisky in the early going). So, where to invest for the second half? Well, there’s lots of chatter about real estate investment trusts, aka REITs, after yesterday’s news that Warren Buffett has taken a big stake in Store Capital 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    STOR, -0.27%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   . REITs can yield big profits — but only if you know which ones to buy, say Bespoke Investment Group analysts for our call of the day. “While the shopping mall REITs have been tanking, the REITs that lease out warehouses to tech companies that need space to house all of their servers and cloud data have been surging,” Bespoke’s team says. “The ten best-performing REITs in 2017 are all in strong uptrends, with the exception of GEO and QCP. If you’re a trend investor, you’ll like these charts,” the analysts add. (They’re referring to Geo Group 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    GEO, +3.33%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   and Quality Care Properties 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    US:QCP

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   .) In other words, tech-exposed and health-care real-estate stocks have had a stellar start to the year and are likely to keep going up. Traditional retail real estate such as malls, however, face “Death by Amazon” as shoppers shift online. That means investors should avoid that type of building, according to Bespoke. “While there has been lots of brainstorming about what to do with malls that often look like ghost towns these days, we haven’t seen any convincing ideas yet (except maybe turning them into tech data centers!),” the analysts say. One of Bespoke’s picks also gets praise from Forbes and Seeking Alpha scribe Brad Thomas, who singles out CareTrust 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    CTRE, +0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   as a “REIT gem” set for relatively speedy earnings growth. As for Buffett’s REIT pick, that’s along the lines of what Bespoke is backing — less than 20% of Store’s portfolio is in traditional retail.                                     US:YMU7

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                   are showing a bigger loss. The dollar index

The shared currency

That drove European stocks

US:GCQ7

The sun is shining again on shares of solar-panel makers, which have been through a rough patch. Now they’re rallying, after President Donald Trump said last week he wanted to clad the long-promised border wall with solar panels, to help pay for it by generating power. That helped send the Guggenheim Solar ETF

But it’s a positive development that Trump’s making a pro-solar statement, they noted, according to The Wall Street Journal. Pandora Media shares 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                            
                                    P, -1.48%

                                   is waving another red flag for the car industry, warning its U.S. auto sales will fall short of forecasts. China’s Premier Li is touting the country’s “unimaginable job growth” at the annual June meeting of the World Economic Forum, which started Tuesday. All sorts of investing views have been getting shared at the Evidence-Based Investing Conference (West): "Amazon/Whole Foods deal is a job killer and is disinflationary" -- Gundlach is not a fan, says he's "allergic" to 200 p/e stocks. #ebiwest The flurry of Fed talk continues today, with Philly Fed’s Patrick Harker and Minneapolis Fed’s Neel Kashkari on tap. The highlight though is Chairwoman Yellen’s speech in London around lunchtime. Read: Don’t expect Janet Yellen to signal retreat on Fed’s interest-rate strategy On the economic docket this morning are the Case-Shiller U.S. home price index and the consumer-confidence index. Professor Steve Hanke from Johns Hopkins University points out that its the first time inflation has spiked above 700% in the country since June 2015. Venezuela’s annual inflation, which I measure daily, soars to 710%. Over 700% not seen since June 2015. pic.twitter.com/cr1rPBDduR The British Queen gets a pay rise, and Twitter isn’t happy about it. Glad we can find more taxpayer money to fix up Buckingham Palace while hundreds of tower blocks are dangerous. Priorities, hey? Author: Sarah Kent
Text: Published: June 29, 2017 1:51 p.m. ET By LONDON -- BP PLC said Thursday it will write off $750 million from its second quarter earnings as a result of poor exploration results in Angola, an oil-rich country that the company has touted as a pillar of its business. The British oil-and-gas company said it would give up its 50% stake in a license off the African country's south coast after deciding it wasn't worth developing a 2014 gas discovery there. BP said additional exploration write-offs in the country will also contribute to the charge, without giving more details. The shift in exploration strategy comes as BP is working to rebuild the company in the wake of its fatal blowout in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 and a three-year plunge in oil prices that has rocked the entire industry. After years of retrenchment, it is now back on the path to growth with plans to add 800,000 barrels a day of new oil and gas production by 2020. By the end of the decade, including its stake in Russian oil giant POA Rosneft, it expects to be pumping 4 million barrels a day -- as much as before the 2010 disaster. BP said the $750 million noncash charge won't be tax deductible, but it also won't affect the company's cash flow for the quarter -- an increasingly important metric for investors worried about oil firms' ability to cover spending and dividend payouts with oil prices stuck below $50 a barrel. BP has operated in Angola for decades and counts its operations there as some of its most important. When BP gained access to deepwater and ultra deepwater exploration licenses off the country's coast in 2011, it described the acquisition as a "major win." Since then, priorities have changed following a precipitous drop in oil prices. Companies are increasingly moving away from expensive exploration in frontier regions, like parts of the Angola that remain relatively unexplored, to focus on areas where they already have operations and knowledge of the geology they are working with. BP said the decision to write off its Angolan assets is part of a broader portfolio review, intended to focus the company more on natural gas and lower-cost oil projects near existing infrastructure. Those types of investments are expected to make the company more resilient in a world where oil prices remain low and more countries shift to lower carbon energy sources like gas and renewables. The company pointed to its decision last year to scrap controversial plans to explore in pristine waters off the coast of Australia. "We are making disciplined choices throughout our business," BP's exploration and production chief Bernard Looney said. "We are choosing not to pursue activities that we don't think will deliver maximum value for our shareholders." Write to Sarah Kent at sarah.kent@wsj.com
Title: BP writes off exploration assets in Angola - MarketWatch

Volume topped 12.5 million shares about 10 minutes after the open, compared with the full-day average of about 460,000 shares, and enough to make it the most actively trade stock on major U.S. exchanges. The stock traded 5.2% above the previous record close of $36.44 on March 18, 2015.
